questions.text: Most common cause of actinomycetoma in India:
Actinomycosis most common site:
Microaerophilic bacteria:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Campylobacter jejuni is the most common species causing gastroenteritis in humans, typically transmitted via contaminated food (especially undercooked poultry), unpasteurized milk, and water. It grows best at 42°C (which mimics the avian intestinal environment) and is commonly cultured on Skirrow's or Campylobacter blood agar under microaerophilic conditions. Why the other options are incorrect: Option (B) Vibrio cholerae Incorrect: Vibrio cholerae is a facultative anaerobe, meaning it can grow in both aerobic and anaerobic conditions. It does not require microaerophilic conditions and thrives in ordinary atmospheric oxygen levels. It is best grown on TCBS (Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile Salts-Sucrose) agar at alkaline pH.
  • • Option (C) Pseudomonas Incorrect: Pseudomonas (especially Pseudomonas aeruginosa) is a strict aerobe, requiring high oxygen levels for growth. It is commonly found in soil, water, and hospital environments, and grows well on MacConkey agar or cetrimide agar.
  • • Option (D) Salmonella Incorrect: Salmonella species are facultative anaerobes, meaning they can grow in both aerobic and anaerobic conditions. They are not microaerophilic. They are commonly isolated on MacConkey agar, XLD agar, or SS agar.
